{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-32934].
  {panel}

As a Confluence user who has started automatically watching a page after editing it, I want to have intuitive and straight-forward user experience for stopping watching that page.

h4. Current State
Currently there are on the upper right corner of page set of controls (see attached image) that clearly and visibly lets user know that it is possible to perform following functions:
* Edit
* Watch 
* Share
* Tools _(this one has visual indicator that lets me know, that i may fold open some kind of menu)_

*Note that there is no visual indicator, that pressing _Watch_ opens something as well!*

h4. Better Solution
In order to address this problem you may improve UX in several ways:
* Add little indicator next to watch button, that hints about possibility to fold open some kind of menu.
* Change watch icon to be enabled/disabled for pages that are either watched or not. For example this "eye" could turn red inside when page is being watched (kind of like the eye of Sauron from the LOTR)
* Change label from _Watch_ to _Stop watching_ or _Manage watches_
* Make a little check mark in the "eye" to indicate that user is watching the page and to encourage user to click there, in case he/she wants to stop watching that page
* Have your UX engineer come up with even better solution

_Disclaimer_ This is not support issue, as I already figured out, that:
*In order to _stop watching_ I have to click _watch_* -- fortunately MS taught us, that in order to turn off computer you have to click _start_ ;)
fields.summary: Improve "Stop Watcing" UX

Confluence does not provided essential library such as MySQL connector {{jra}} file out of the box. This make users need to add it manually before they install Confluence.

It shouldn't be a problem for standalone as the installation directory is available before they start Confluence. However it is not the case for *installer* version of Confluence.

In installer version, the installation directory will not be available until the installer successfully deploy Confluence. Hence user will need to restart Confluence after it started to applied the necessary library file.

*Implementation Suggestion*

Installer version should provide a feature where it could ask user to upload the necessary library *before* it *start* Confluence. Hence, it is not necessary to restart Confluence to applied the library and a streamline process could be achieve for the users installing Confluence using installer method.

In corporate settings with many non-public spaces it would be helpful to be able to delegate the management of group memberships to space admins in order to relieve confluence-admins of this task.

Example:
Spaces: X, Y
Groups: X-admins, X-developers, X-users, Y-admins, Y-developers, Y-users

As it is, only confluence-admins can edit membership in all three groups.

It would be better to be able to assign membership-edit privileges regarding X-developers and X-users to the members of X-admins and those regarding Y-developers and Y-users to the members of Y-admins. 
That way, confluence-admins would only need to create the groups and assign privileges once and the space admins could do the rest.

It is, of course, possible to assign individual privileges to users per space, but using groups is much superior when a lot of users are involved.
fields.summary: Delegate group membership management to space admins

fields.description:
You cannot navigate to the editor controls using the tab key.  Although many of these controls are accessible via shortcuts and other means, there should be a means of getting to any control displayed onscreen using the keyboard.  Ideally the tab key would focus on the whole panel and the cursor keys would allow navigation within the panel.   

This is a failure in meeting Level A of the WCAG 2.0.

For an example of how this has been done well, check out the CK editor: http://ckeditor.com/

For examples on how to do toolbars well, check out this link:

http://test.cita.illinois.edu/aria/toolbar/index.php
fields.summary: Cannot navigate to or operate toolbar controls in the editor using only a keyboard...

fields.description:
Accesskey attributes are an older approach to helping users navigate through a page, which are not well supported and can cause problems with existing shortcuts.  In many cases a user will already have a binding that takes precedence and the accesskey binding will be basically useless.

We have two in Confluence.  For the search shortcut ("q"), we already provide an alternate shortcut, so mostly the concern is with the "L" binding to jump to the main content of the page.

The preferred approach is now to also use the HTML5 "main" and "nav" elements to satisfy the kind of content-based grouping that the "L" binding is used for.

This is required to meet Level AA compatibility with the WCAG 2.0 standard.
fields.summary: Supplement accesskey hints...

fields.description:
When navigating through the view page interface using tabs, there are many invisible page stops which are reflected in the "status" area of the browser's footer, but which do not result in any on-screen change.  This is an issue for people who use the keyboard to navigate.

Examples include (but are not limited to):

# The space logo, which gains focus after leaving the "sign up" link, but which does not give any indication that it is highlighted.
# The tab stops before and after the "view page attachments" link are not displayed on screen but can be reached using the keyboard.  These are links hidden using the css option "display=none".  You can hide these using a technique like setting the tabindex to -1.

To satisfy this, someone should go through the entire view page interface in a loop with tab navigation and either hide or make obvious what is selected at every stop.
fields.summary: Remove invisible page stops...

fields.description:
The quick search in the top menu opens a drop-down list of suggestions.  These suggestions use the tab key for navigation, which prevents users from moving beyond the suggestion dialog to (for example) the help menu.

Users who are logged in will automatically see recently viewed pages and immediately encounter this problem.

The same is true of the help and user profile menus, although those do not automatically open.

The preferred behavior is to use the arrow keys to navigate within the list and reserve the tab key for moving into and out of the parent menu.

This is a requirement to meet Level AA of the WCAG 2.0 standard.
fields.summary: Drop-down menus trap tab-focus...

fields.description:
Although you can use the tab key to navigate to the app switcher (triple horizontal bar icon) and to the top-level drop-down menus (spaces for example), you cannot open the dialogs with a keyboard.

This is a basic requirement to meet the lowest-level of WCAG 2.0 compliance.
fields.summary: App switcher and other menu options cannot be opened using the keyboard...

fields.description:
If you tab through the links and controls within the view page interface, you either cannot select the tools menu using the tab controls, or the fact that you have selected them is not indicated in any way.

As a result, you cannot perform basic operation accessed through the tools menu using only a keyboard.  You can only access the control with a mouse, which is a big no-no.

This is another key gap that prevents Confluence from satisfying even the lowest required compliance levels of the WCAG 2.0 standard.
fields.summary: Tools menu is not accessible via a keyboard...

fields.description: Common dialogs like the create menu don't have tab stops. In combination with CONF-12383, this makes much of Confluence unusable with a keyboard and breaks the most basic level of compatibility with the WCAG 2.0 standard that has already been made a requirement for the Australian, Canadian, German, and many other world governments.
fields.summary: Dialog elements need to support keyboard controls...

fields.description:
When a dialog ("insert attachment", for example) is opened, the keyboard navigation focus remains with the background window.  If you hit the "tab" key, you can see the focus moving between links in the background.  The focus never (or seemingly never) comes to the dialog.

The keyboard focus and input should only work within the dialog until the dialog is closed, and the focus should move to a reasonable starting point within the dialog when the dialog is created.

This is a key sticking point in meeting even basic [WCAG 2.0 Compliance|http://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG20/].  Confluence wouldn't meet even Level A (the minimum required for most government clients). 

The problem also negatively impacts power users who are trying to take advantage of our keyboard shortcuts in combination with the usual browser conventions.
fields.summary: Keyboard focus should move to dialogs when they open...

There are currently two ways (that I know of) to create a new Jira issue from Confluence:

1) In Edit mode, use the Jira Issues macro to create a new issue.
2) Not in edit mode, select some text and click the Jira icon in the tiny menu that pops up.

These two methods present two different interfaces. Using the Jira issues macro, one must select from a non-filterable list of all possible projects. However, the UI will properly allow filling in values for required fields, as per CONF-23424.

Using the text-selection method, the associated UI has a very nice filterable project picker, but cannot create issues in Jira projects which have any customization of the required fields (such as Component, which is mandatory in our projects).

I would argue that these two should provide an entirely identical UX. (I also think they should fully implement CONF-23424 but that is, literally, a separate issue).

Customer addressed this:
{quote}
We'd like to use - the very common - default logical AND operator for searches of our content in Confluence.
Can't find a config option in Confluence to switch the default Lucene OR operator to AND.
Is this not configurable ?
{quote}
And it is related with https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-30974

Note:
The default search operator is OR although in [2006 we made AND available|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-5874].

This is not configurable though and it is an intended change to the searching algorithm. Due to the way that the phrase ranking works, it shouldn't be a problem though, because it should include all of the "AND" matches already, and they should be ranked the highest. What this means is the results will read like:
# All of the "AND" results appear first
# Results with less keyword matches will appear below, in order of how many keywords match, highest to lowest

Customer would like to have the option of AND/OR search.

  {panel}

This may or may not be a duplicate of [#CONF-17621], about EXIF rotation, marked as "won't fix".  I understand from that issue that there is some debate about whether this is Confluence's issue or a browser issue.  Let me explain my experience.

# I take a picture with my iPhone, it displays it the correct way up
# I email it to myself, Gmail displays it the correct way up
# I accidentally import it into my Google Drive, it displays it the correct way up
# I download it to my Mac, it display it the correct way up
# I import it into Confluence, it displays it the wrong way round
# I start writing this ticket, and have an idea or two...
# I access it in Chrome using a file:// URI, it displays it the right way up
# I boot a Windows 7 VM and ping it over there, it displays it the right way up (perhaps a file:// URI in IE6 would be the nail in the coffin?)


{panel:title=Atlassian Status as of February 14, 2017|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5| titleBGColor=#3C78B5| bgColor=#E7F4FA}

Hi All,

Thank you for your feedback on this issue thus far. This is certainly an issue which has done its round on the internet over the years for many browser and application vendors alike, with each pointing the finger at each other as to whether the application or browser should observe the EXIF rotation metadata.

The obvious solution is for all browsers to support the 'image-orientation' CSS, however after many years this is still only supported by Firefox.
We have explored no less than 6 different solutions to this issue as each brings pros and cons in terms of performance, behaviour and complexity.
As a result of this exercise, it has been decided that image rotation would be done server side based on the EXIF rotation metadata.

The actual implementation is somewhat different for Server and Cloud deployments, and thus the rollout/delivery may occur at different times, however is high up in the queue right now.

Confluence Product Management
{panel}

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-32752].
  {panel}

For the sake of:
* Performance
* Troubleshooting
* Indexing bugs

...It can be desirable to have an option to not index the _contents_ of any attachments in Confluence. Our [current process|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFKB/How+Do+I+Disable+Indexing+of+Attachments] to disable attachment index via disabling a number of extractors is an okay workaround, but does not disable indexing of ALL attachments. Text/HTML/XML files are still indexed and cannot be disabled via the UI. This presents problems since the Lucene upgrade in Confluence 5.2 introduces new bugs can hang the entire indexing process such as:
* https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-32566
* https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LUCENE-5400

However, even if the bugs (and other future Lucene bugs that may arise) are fixed, one may wish to forgo attachment indexing for the sake of improving Confluence performance.

This request is to add an option in the UI to simply disable all attachment contents. The permanent equivalent of issuing a POST request {{http://<confluence_url>/rest/prototype/latest/index/reindex}}
with {{Content-Type: application/json}} and form data {{option = CONTENT_ONLY}}.
fields.summary: Option in the UI to disable all attachment content indexing in Confluence

Hi, 
We are running the latest version of Confluence on CentOS 6.5 64bit and we encountered a problem that led us to discover that some of your support documentation is lacking in information or currently inaccurate. 

We had the exact same symptoms as mentioned in this article:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=361725953
"Could not open Space Tools or Manage Space Permissions or Delete Spaces."
So we followed the article and entered the SQL query into the correct database. This returned that there was no such table as 'confluence.bandana' 

Then we followed a commenter's suggestion to clear the plugin cache. We followed this article:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFKB/How+to+Clear+Confluence+Plugins+Cache
Just two notes on this:
- The article does not mention to backup directories before nuking.
- The <confluence-home> was actually in /var/applicationdata instead of the assumed /opt/ directory.

I hope this has been of help for your team.

Regards,
Pat

There is a request from customer to be able to improve search algorithm so that pages that have been edited recently will get higher weight than those which haven't.

As described on the following document [Ranking of Search Results|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONF51/Ranking+of+Search+Results], there is a weighting of search result based on age. However, it only calculates the age from the creation of the item which means the ranking weights newer item higher but does not take into account the recently edited item.

Please assess the possibility of improving the ranking of search result as per above condition.

Thank you and regards,
Lazuardi
